awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A Virtual Community of Practice to Promote LGBTQ Inclusion in Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent research on the experiences of lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and queer (LGBTQ) individuals in engineering has shown that the climate can be unfriendly (or "chilly") for both students and professionals.  This project aims to increase the inclusion of LGBTQ students and professionals in engineering. It will provide support for new approaches to foster inclusion and research on how to enable faculty and staff to become change agents. The project will identify issues faced by LGBTQ students and professionals in engineering, identify and implement strategies to create more welcoming engineering environments, and disseminate those strategies so that they can be expanded to a national level.  Successful completion of this project will result in the implementation of policies and practices in engineering environments to increase inclusion and participation of LGBTQ students and professionals. In addition, it will determine the usefulness of a Virtual Community of Practice model for efforts such as this to address other societal issues.

A chilly climate for LGBTQ individual can be found in every sector of STEM professions, where cultural norms and professional ideologies make it difficult to recognize and rectify exclusionary practices.  One negative consequence of this chilly environment is difficulty in recruiting and retaining talented LGBTQ individuals into the engineering profession. This project uses qualitative research to generate new knowledge about the processes of developing a community of practice to promote LGBTQ inclusion in engineering, how the members of the community develop into change agents, and what strategies are effective in reshaping norms and increasing LGBTQ inclusion in engineering departments.  The results will be translated into practice through the iterative refinement of Virtual Community of Practice activities and implementation of promising practices to advance LGBTQ inclusion in engineering departments.  In addition, the research will be the basis of systematic development and formative refinement of an online SafeZone course to provide inclusion training to engineering students and professionals nationwide. The impact of this project will extend beyond the boundaries of engineering to STEM more broadly, as the Virtual Community of Practice members will include members from the various STEM fields.

por.por_cntn:
The project addressed the overall research question: “How does a virtual community of practice develop to create an inclusive climate for LGBTQ+ individuals in engineering and STEM”? A Virtual Community of Practice comprised of engineering and science faculty and graduate students offers a mechanism for to share knowledge, ideas and resources, and to support one another as they develop and implement action plans to promote LGBTQ equality in their engineering departments and colleges. Safe Zone workshops seek to create a network of engineering faculty, staff, and students with the awareness, knowledge and skills to create an inclusive environment for LGBTQ faculty and students. To explore this important topic, we have been working on the following goal and research questions:

The goal of this project is to create an inclusive climate for LGBTQ individuals in engineering and identify most effective strategies for reshaping norms and creating LGBTQ-inclusive STEM departments

RQ1: How do COP characteristics develop in the VCP focused on LGBTQ inclusion in STEM?

RQ2: How do members of the VCP develop a change agent identity integrated with their engineering identity?

The STEM and engineering education community must do more to attract and retain members of the queer community to enhance our field and our efforts for broadening participation in engineering. The study generated the following outcomes:

1) The project team has produced one book, three conference papers, and two manuscripts under development with submission targets over the next year. Future papers will include: (A) the  characterization of a VCP members who have a developed advocacy identity and (B) a proposed model to describe the development of an advocacy identity among VCP members, with the support of the VCP community.

2) The research team worked collaboratively to develop manuscripts as PI Cross consulted the team on ways to separate data for multiple manuscripts under development. Over the course of the project 2 graduate researchers and 3 post doc scholars were involved in all phases of data analysis and manuscript development. 

3) The study explores STEM professionals’ identity as advocates and we integrated two existing advocate identity frameworks to understand the development and enactment of an LGBTQ+ advocate identity in engineering and other STEM contexts. The two frameworks include “Becoming an Advocate” (Goodman et al. 2018) and “LGBTQ+ Faculty Activism” (Messinger 2011). The “Becoming an Advocate” framework describes a process of how an individual develops their advocate identity which actively protects a member of a vulnerable group like the queer community. A major product of our study was a codebook that characterizes the experiences of VCP members.

4) Research Findings: From the qualitative data, we found i.) participants felt a need to change engineering culture to more support LGBTQ+ persons in academia, and VCP group support was key in enabling participants’ advocate identity development. ii) some participants were emboldened to “rock boats.”, iii) the Revealing Oppression Creates Knowledge that Individuals Need Groups (ROCKING) model is situated within power and privilege when encouraging development as an advocate, and iv) the developed identity revealed 2 themes and 5 subthemes.  Theme 1 was professional identity with two subthemes of engineering identity and educator identity. Theme 2 was the LGBTQ+ Advocacy with three subthemes of time including past, present, and future.

5) Project Impact: To date, Safe Zone (SZ) Ally Training workshops facilitated by our project team and VCP members have directly trained 1,450+ individuals over a total of 90 workshops. These workshops have been offered at ASEE Annual Conferences, professional society events, college campuses, and online. The results of the research component of the project is used to refine SZ content and improve the VCP. Also, the VCP activities including SZ facilitation contribute to members developing an advocacy identity.

  1. Safe Zone Workshop Evaluation: 2021 Safe Zone workshop attendees were asked to complete surveys designed to evaluate the impacts and quality of the workshops. Results from the surveys indicate that the workshops continue to be a positive and impactful educational experience for participants. A total of 121 individuals attended the workshops, with 32 completing a post-workshop survey (a 26% response rate). Responses were generally positive: Level 1(N=14), Level 2 (N=13), and Trans Allyship (N=4).
  2. VCP Evaluation: Eight respondents have been engaged with the VCP for six or more years, while four have been involved for three years or less. Results indicate that the VCP has built a strong community and serves as a source of support for participants. Respondents described how participating in the VCP provided them with a sense of community and support, both personally and in their work for LGBTQ+ equality.
